# THE CITY OF EL SEGUNDO GENERAL PLAN 1992

Adopted: December 1, 1992
Ordinance Number: 1189

## City Council
Carl Jacobson, Mayor
J.B. Wise, Mayor Pro Tem
Michael Robbins, Councilmember
Richard Switz, Councilmember
Alan West, Councilmember

## Planning Commission
Elizabeth Kennedy, Chairwoman
Raymond L. Davis, III, Vice-Chair
Brian Crowley, Commissioner
Sean Mahon, Commissioner
Gordon Leon, Commissioner

## City Manager
Frank V. Meehan

Director of Planning and Building Safety
Hyrum B. Fedje

## Prepared with the Assistance of
The Lightfoot Planning Group
Basmaciyan-Darnell, Inc.
EIP Associates
Coopers & Lybrand
SCS Engineers

## Table of Contents
1. Introduction
2. Economic Development Element
3. Land Use Element
4. Circulation Element
5. Housing Element
6. Open Space and Recreation Element
7. Conservation Element
8. Air Quality Element
9. Noise Element
10. Public Safety Element
11. Hazardous Materials and Waste Management Element
    Appendix

## Introduction

### General Plan Summary
A general plan is a document that reflects the values and contains the goals of a community with respect to development. It is a statement of policy, with text and diagrams, that is used as a tool for helping decision makers make decisions that are consistent with community goals. The state planning code of California requires every city and county to adopt a general plan. The government code also requires the plan to be an integrated, internally consistent document in which policies do not conflict with each other.

There are seven elements that are required by state law to be contained in every general plan: Land Use, Noise, Circulation, Housing, Open Space, Conservation, and Safety. Optional elements may also be included to address topics of local interest which relate to the physical development of the community, such as Air Quality and Economic Development.

The general plan is comprehensive in nature and content. It covers the entire geographic area that is located within the city limits, and it addresses a broad range of issues relating to the physical, economic, and social development of the community.

### Overview of the City
The City of El Segundo is located in the Los Angeles urban area. It is considered part of the Airport/South Bay subregion at the southwestern edge of the Los Angeles coastal basin. Downtown Los Angeles is about 20 freeway miles from El Segundo.

The City itself is 5.46 square miles (3,494.4 acres), with a resident population, per the 1990 Census, of 15,223 people and a considerably larger daytime (employee) population of approximately 80,000.

To the north is Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in the City of Los Angeles. To the east is Del Aire, which is an island of Los Angeles County, as well as the City of Hawthorne. The City of Manhattan Beach is directly south of El Segundo. To the west of El Segundo is the Pacific Ocean.

## City Facilities
1. Recreation Park
2. Library Park
3. Hilltop Park
4. Acacia Park
5. Washington Park
6. Candy Cane Park
7. Sycamore Parkette
8. Kansas Parkette
9. Constitution Park
10. Library
11. Middle School
12. El Segundo High School
13. Continuation School
14. Elementary School
15. Civic Center Downtown Area

structured_data.overview: This document is the 1992 General Plan for the City of El Segundo, California. It outlines the city's development goals, policies, and planning elements as required by California state law. The plan covers the entire geographic area within city limits and addresses physical, economic, and social development issues.

structured_data.other_info: The City of El Segundo is 5.46 square miles (3,494.4 acres), with a resident population of 15,223 people (1990 Census) and a daytime employee population of approximately 80,000. It is located in the Los Angeles urban area, part of the Airport/South Bay subregion. The city borders Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) to the north, Del Aire and Hawthorne to the east, Manhattan Beach to the south, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. City facilities include Recreation Park, Library Park, Hilltop Park, Acacia Park, Washington Park, Candy Cane Park, Sycamore Parkette, Kansas Parkette, Constitution Park, Library, Middle School, El Segundo High School, Continuation School, Elementary School, and Civic Center Downtown Area.
